intro: Galium gerardi var. venustum, commonly known as the showy bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white to pinkish flowers that are clustered in cymes, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its flowers are often visited by various pollinators, including bees and flies, contributing to its ecological significance. The plant thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
